review_title: Ask questions at the interview, request transparency.
pros: Professionals wishing to move up the ladder- this would be your organization to grow!
cons:
Inexperienced leadership. 
Retention efforts recognized as non- existent. Costly to the organization and patient care. (Noted other organizations can and do work to keep their employees and demonstrate willingness and know-how to plug applicants into roles they may be more fitted for, if not for the role they applied for.) 
Lack of information passed from senior leadership though the managers to staff and from staff through the managers up to senior leadership. Additionally, there is no cohesion between facilities and areas in the organization- left and right hands aren't aware of what the other is doing. 
This small organization continues to make budget cuts at a time when other organizations show  productive growth and positive changes for employees, patients, and visitors.

pros: I have now been with ProHealth Care for a year and a half. They took a chance and hired me when most employers would have passed me over because of prior work history. I had documented medical issues and my attendance at previous jobs suffered. They brought me on with not many expectations and I flourished, proving that I was in fact a valuable asset and a good, dedicated, and hard working employee. In return, I have been treated like I am part of the family, not just a faceless employee. My hard work and dedication has been recognized and continues to be rewarded. I plan on staying with ProHealth Care for the long term. I plan on returning to school in fall. I am 37 currently and if I pursue an education in the medical field and maintain good grades, ProHealth Care will reimburse up to 80% of my tuition costs (last time I checked!). ProHealth Care  offers competitive pay, great benefits, and has been a great place to work for.
cons: The only real downside of my employment here so far is that there are very few full time positions in my specific job category.

pros: Good people that care work here
cons: Senior leadsership not really engaged

pros: Competitive pay, Good benefits, Good location

review_title: "Just Culture" is only liked by employees who would have been fired from another company
job_title: Patient Access Scheduler in Brookfield, WI
pros: Finally raised the wage because so many employees left after management changes last year. I am close to retirement so not too many years left here.
cons: WORST MANAGEMENT I HAVE EVER WORKED WITH!!  Working with uneducated loud crazy women because they are so desperate for people and can't retain people. If you want a socialist environment, then come on in and apply. Poor work ethic, not too smart, victimhood and entitlement are not frowned upon, instead the intelligent employees will just have to pick up your work and JUST CULTURE will give you a positive thumbs up for effort. Not kidding!! Employees are not held to the same standard and management retaliates selectively. Careful and come in with tough back skin. You never know who holds the dagger. Did I mention it is run by ALL WOMEN?! Not a healthy environment and there is a reason no one transfers internally to this crap show,

pros: Good benefits, relatively competitive pay, great co-workers.  Dept Mgr was awesome- very level-headed, intelligent, and approachable.
cons: Long hours that really interfered with ability to see and spend time with family.  I started out full-time for quite awhile, then reduced my status because I couldn't manage the work schedule any longer. The upper management at my location plays blatant "favorites" with other departments at the expense of others, and are completely out of touch with what goes on in day-to-day workings of the clinic. Decisions that directly affect our everyday work are made with very little employee input. Then, turn out to be an inefficient workflow. Employees work 12+ hr shifts with no help with coverage so someone can actually take a real meal break and sit somewhere away from their workstation and patients.  Patients allowed to check in 1 minute before closing and be seen for anything.

pros: The pay is good, it has a community feeling, friendly staff, and rated #1 employer in the state of Wisconsin by Forbes.
cons: I really don’t have any. I’m not looking to leave.

pros: positive work environment, competitive pay
cons: I have no complaints from my time with this company

review_title: ProHealth is a great place to work
pros: Teamwork, respect, flexibility, good benefits
cons: Distance from home, low salary

pros: Great co-workers, good food if you can get to the cafeteria, free parking
cons: They are starting to forget about the patients.  There is no work/life balance.  Little appreciation is shown to employees.  High employee turnover.

review_title: Bait & Switch philosophy towards new employees, head in the sand mentality to battle with Aurora.  Avoid at all costs!
pros: Benefits are ok.  Thats about it.
cons: Dictatorial mentality towards employees - both professional and non-professional.  Management not in touch with reality and fighting a losing battle with Aurora.  They have absolutely no idea how to nurture the practices of the doctors they hire.  Back office staff are under qualified and turn over frequently.  Management cheap towards tenured staff and have cut opportunities for showing appreciation.  They have terminated many tenured nurses - I along with a whole bunch of other nurse friends of mine were coldly and cruelly terminated a few years ago after working our butts off for years for these people.  Get a clue, "leaders".  Fire the whole bunch.  They aren't going to survive anyway - ha ha!  Aurora will drive them out of business.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Hartland, WI
pros: 3 month orientation including mock visits in a home setting with mock patients that allows for ability to ask questions to educator during learning process. Great innovative idea. Very valuable! You are such an independent practitioner in the home environment, that you need a lot of training and support to be confident in this role. ProHealth Home Care gives that support with classroom setting, precepting, and the above mentioned mock visits.
cons: Pay was not as equitable as it should've been a couple years ago, but now there was an equity increase and PHHC is competitive in the market. Good job in making a negative into a positive!

pros: In some divisions there is great culture and work/life balance, while in others I hear it is very oppressive.  It depends on which area you are working.
cons: I've worked here for over a decade and they have the absolute worst benefit package of any employer I've worked for - which are several.  They tout themselves as offering a great benefits package but their insurance plan requires you to use their doctors to receive in-network benefits and if they don't have someone available in their hospital/clinic system in a specialty you need, they require you to drive to Madison to seek services through UW Health rather than visit a competing healthcare provider locally who has numerous capable doctors that could be options.

pros:
I love working at West Wood Health and Fitness. Management is good. The facility is kept up-to-date and really clean.
The members and staff are fun to work with and one learns from them.
cons: Sometimes everyone needs a substitute for their work hours on a given day. Many employees are accommodating, but it is hard to find replacements for evenings and weekends.

pros: Fairly good benefits although each year they are more costly with less coverage
cons: I have worked for PHC for over a decade and I can tell you that PHC is in a constant state of reorganization.  They bring in consultants on a regular basis to evaluate where they can cut costs and it is always the same answer - reduce staff.  Employee moral is so low because they are always in fear of losing their jobs.  Management controls the employees with a culture of fear, favoritism, and secrecy.  Employees are quitting on a regular basis because the stress that is put on them is ridiculous.  This makes it more difficult for those that are left because in the spirit of cutting costs the positions are not filled and the work is put on those that are left in the department.  PHC says they operate in a "Just Culture" but that isn't true.   This company has a culture that is run by it's blatant favoritism by management.  If you are not one of the favorites, you can assume you will get the least desirable duties, and you will be micromanaged so they can document all errors.  This is done in hopes that you will quite and so that they have a documented reason for not giving you a raise.  If you do get a raise, you are lucky if you get 2%.  They tell you straight out that it is not possible to score high enough in your review to get a decent raise.

pros: The insurance benefits are excellent.
cons: Compensation is mediocre. Management is constantly changing work hours and schedules to meet the demands of a consulting firm hired to cut costs. As a result many jobs have been eliminated and employees are forced to do twice the amount of work in less time. There is very little support from management and morale is at an all time low. I would not recommend this company to any one.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Lake Success, NY
pros: Co workers are great people!!
cons:
Below industry pay with very low raises 
No possible Growth,
Horrible Health ins options.
Horrible retirement plans.
Office managers  do not care about employees.

pros: Great front line staff that have the passion to do the right thing and help
cons: More time is spent doing duplicate or triplicate documentation in multiple places than the time it takes to make an update or fix. Treating EMR same as IT changes is not appropriate and is keeping Prohealth from leading the area in functionality.

review_title: Total Emotional and Character tear down
job_title: Patient Account Representative in Brookfield, WI
pros: Hours are great, patients are for the most part pretty amazing, PTO adds up quickly,  starting pay competitive.
cons:
The managers and Supervisors are constantly tearing you down. They say they want to build you up, however make you feel the size of a pea during the process. I have never in my life been told how many tasks I am doing wrong without any “real” help being offered to solve the issues. 
Holidays are not paid time off on the Company’s dime as most facilities and employers offer. You may have holidays off and be paid for them, but that pay is coming out of your own saved and earned Paid Time Off already accrued. If you do not have any PTO saved up, well then it’s just a day off without pay.
The treatment of all employees is not equal. One can be treated one way, reprimanded for discrepancies, yet the employee sitting next to them has free rein to do everything the other employee was written up or scolded for.
Training is not universal. One manager says one thing, the other something different. One employee has tasks counted while 98% of the other employees haven’t heard of any counted tasks since beginning their employment over 10+ years ago. Why not have a set training program or schedule for all employees that is identical? 
Older adults are discriminated against at the Company. Instead of showing Respect to the Employee who has given you 25+ years, they are treated badly and unfairly and literally kicked out the door. 
Very sad. Very unfair. Terrible place to work.

review_title: They have management issues which I understand have only gotten worse since I left in 2011.
pros: Work/life balance was fairly good.
cons: There are a lot of unhappy people here who want to leave. The corporate culture doesn't leave one with a positive feeling.

pros: benefits, certain people are good to work with
cons: management overturned so much until they landed on someone so horrible. management did not care about you, your family, or your health. In fact, this place made your health even worse. Negative thing if you are sick or if your children are sick. once they find someone to pick on, they make your life miserable until you quit or are fired.  they do not want to see you grow.

job_title: Document Imaging Specialist in Wauwatosa, WI
pros: Quality of care and attention provided for patients, commitment to philanthropy and charitable organizations to support the local community.  Good benefits and 401K program.
cons: Lack of employee morale, very little communication between staff and management.  Very weak employee career development program.  An overall stagnant and stale corporate culture and work environment.

pros: Collaborative team environment where my ideas are heard and acted upon. PHC is forward thinking and staff are encouraged to bring forward ideas and more efficient ways of doing things.
cons: Maternity / Paternity leave policy - if both parents are staff members the 12 weeks of FML is combined. This means that if new mom wants to take 12 weeks, new dad cannot take any time off (unless using PTO). This is a very outdated practice and should be reviewed.

review_title: 20 years was great and then a new manager who was not nice at all
pros: PTO, most of the people were great to work with. Cooperation among the "workers" was great, but ideas don't get implemented without managers buying in.
cons: Management that abuse the system and an HR team that doesn't care.  They have these mission and value statements, but they are just words if they are not put to use.

pros: The pros about working with Prohealth Care were the great coworkers, the excellent physicians and staff, and very good benefits.
cons: Unfortunately, the new upper management has turned the focus away from patient care and on to business profitablility.  Upper management also does not understand how their changes directly affect morale and patient care.

pros:
Proximity....if you live in Waukesha County, otherwise there aren't any.

Used to be one of the best employers in Waukesha. No longer.

State of the art facilities
cons: Absolutely evil upper management.  It is obvious their only goal is to tear down the company and sell it.  The way they treat their employees, especially the physicians, is deplorable; people are nothing but commodities. Only chance for upward mobility with the current structure is to play political game and /or buy into the current agenda.

pros: this is a small community focused hospital system that has a reputation of providing good health care.  Facilities are lovely and caregiver staff is talented.
cons: Organization is being dismantled in the name of efficiency and gutted of everything that gave it distinction.  Leadership seems to enjoy slashing the budget ---including ending community outreach nursing---while rewarding themselves with generous bonuses. Management governs by fear and secrecy leaving staff wondering day by day about their future and eroding trust in each other.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Waukesha, WI
pros: my coworkers are awesome people
cons: feeling unvalued by corporate folks

job_title: Home Health RN in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Good pay, autonomy, good benefits
cons: Often go into toxic environments in home care, smokers, filth, hoarders, dealing with Medicare rules and regs, computers that continually malfunction and waste time.  (and, they're new)

pros: Love the sense of community, everyone is willing to help out
cons: I did not feel a sense of empathy from direct management

cons: Some healthcare system surrounded by larger, dominant healthcare systems.
